'''sudo''' (''super user do''; officially {{pronEng|ËsuËduË}},<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gratisoft.us/sudo/ |title=Sudo Main Page |author=Miller, Todd C |accessdate=2007-03-05}}</ref> though {{IPA|/ËsuËdoÊ/}} is also common) is a [[computer program|program]] for [[Unix-like]] computer [[operating system]]s that allows users to run programs with the security privileges of another user (normally the [[superuser]]). By default, sudo will prompt for a user password but it may be configured to require the root password or no password at all.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gratisoft.us/sudo/man/sudo.html |title=Manpage for sudo |accessdate=2007-11-04}}</ref> sudo is able to log each command run and in some cases has completely supplanted the superuser login for administrative tasks, most notably in [[Ubuntu (Linux distribution)|Ubuntu]] Linux and Apple's [[Mac OS X]].<ref>[https://help.ubuntu.com/community/RootSudo RootSudo - Community Ubuntu Documentation<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.macdevcenter.com/pub/a/mac/2002/10/22/macforunix.html MacDevCenter.com - Top Ten Mac OS X Tips for Unix Geeks<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
+
'''sudo''' (''super user do''; officially {{pronEng|ËsuËduË}},<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gratisoft.us/sudo/ |title=Sudo Main Page |author=Miller, Todd C |accessdate=2007-03-05}}</ref> though {{IPA|/ËsuËdoÊ/}} is also common) is a [[computer program|program]] for [[Unix-like]] computer [[operating system]]s that allows users to run programs with the security privileges of another user (normally the [[superuser]]). By default, sudo will prompt for a user password but it may be configured to require the root password or no password at all.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gratisoft.us/sudo/man/sudo.html |title=Manpage for sudo |accessdate=2007-11-04}}</ref> sudo is able to log each command run and in some cases has completely supplanted the superuser login for administrative tasks, most notably in [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]] Linux and Apple's [[Mac OS X]].<ref>[https://help.ubuntu.com/community/RootSudo RootSudo - Community Ubuntu Documentation<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.macdevcenter.com/pub/a/mac/2002/10/22/macforunix.html MacDevCenter.com - Top Ten Mac OS X Tips for Unix Geeks<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
sudo was originally written by Bob Coggeshall and Cliff Spencer "around 1980" at the Department of [[Computer Science]] at [[University at Buffalo, The State University of New York|SUNY/Buffalo]]. The current version is maintained by [[List of OpenBSD developers|OpenBSD developer]] Todd C. Miller and distributed under a [[BSD License|BSD-style]] license.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gratisoft.us/sudo/history.html|title=A Brief History of Sudo|author=Miller, Todd C|accessdate=2007-03-05}}</ref>
sudo was originally written by Bob Coggeshall and Cliff Spencer "around 1980" at the Department of [[Computer Science]] at [[University at Buffalo, The State University of New York|SUNY/Buffalo]]. The current version is maintained by [[List of OpenBSD developers|OpenBSD developer]] Todd C. Miller and distributed under a [[BSD License|BSD-style]] license.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gratisoft.us/sudo/history.html|title=A Brief History of Sudo|author=Miller, Todd C|accessdate=2007-03-05}}</ref>
